captions.text: Welcome to the League of Legends Champion Spotlight featuring Ashe, the Frost Archer.
Ashe is a long ranged Marksman who specializes in heavy-hitting critical strikes and kiting enemies with ice-enchanted arrows.
With exceptional lane and crowd control,
Ashe excels as a primary damage dealer while initiating fights or assisting allies from across the map.
Ashe’s passive is Focus.
Whenever Ashe isn’t using basic attacks,
her critical strike chance increases over time, reaching a maximum of one hundred percent faster at higher levels.
Ashe’s first basic attack consumes the critical strike bonus from Focus, but casting an ability won’t reset it.
Frost Shot causes each of Ashe’s basic attacks to slow enemy movement speed,
while consuming mana on each hit when toggled on.
Toggle Frost Shot on to keep enemies at bay, or to hold them in range to pick up a kill.
When using Volley, Ashe blankets the target area in a cone of arrows.
Each arrow stops on the first enemy hit; dealing physical damage and applying the slow from Frost Shot.
No more than one arrow can hit a single enemy in a Volley.
Far off targets can dodge the attack by ducking between arrows or hiding behind other units.
Since Volley inherits the slow from Frost Shot, it won’t freeze enemies if Frost Shot hasn’t been leveled.
Hawkshot, has a passive and active effect. Passively, it grants her bonus gold whenever she kills an enemy.
When activated, Ashe sends out a hawk to a target location,
revealing the surrounding area (including brush), but not invisibility, for a few seconds.
Hawkshot has a very long range, allowing her to scout key map locations, or check for incoming threats.
Ashe’s ultimate, Enchanted Crystal Arrow, fires a giant arrow off in a target direction.
This arrow travels indefinitely until it collides with an enemy champion or flies off the map.
If it connects, the arrow shatters on impact,
damaging and stunning the champion it hits, while slowing and damaging enemies in the surrounding area.
The stun duration varies greatly, gaining intensity the further it travels across the map.
At the start of every game, Focus can guarantee a critical hit as long as you don’t attack any enemies on your way to the lane.
This makes Ashe particularly potent in a level 1 team fight.
Here, Ashe uses Volley and the critical hit from Focus
to instantly take out nearly half of Tristana’s health, and help secure First Blood.
Early game, Volley is Ashe’s primary source of burst damage, and helps apply pressure on lane opponents.
Since Volley isn’t tied to her basic attack, she casts it immediately after hitting Ezreal to bully him away from the minion wave.
Though it lacks the burst damage of Volley, Frost Shot is another excellent tool for harassing enemy champions.
Here, Ashe uses it to establish lane dominance over Graves, tagging him with additional attacks as he attempts to disengage.
Frost Shot and Volley also make a destructive combo when combined. Here, Ashe slows Ezreal to prevent him from chasing Thresh.
As soon he attempts to escape through the brush,
Volley keeps him locked down long enough for Ashe to catch up, closing out the kill before turning to Zyra.
Although it’s primarily used for scouting, Hawkshot’s also an important tool for sticking to an enemy that’s attempting to juke.
Here, Ashe reveals Blitzcrank as he attempts to use the brush to cover his escape,
allowing her to connect an additional Frost Shot to continue the chase.
Ashe’s strong kiting abilities also enable her to play more aggressively in lane.
When Darius comes to gank, she’s able to disengage, keeping enemies at bay by spamming Frost Shot and Volley.
Ashe soon becomes the aggressor again, using Frost Shot to keep up the chase once Darius over extends.
Ashe helps finish off Darius when her lane partner lands the hook, then turns to pressure the enemy Carry.
Flashing to safety, she immediately follows up with Frost Shot and Volley
to keep Ezreal from escaping as Shen arrives to close out the kill.
Once Ashe hits Level 6, the extreme range on Enchanted Crystal Arrow makes Ashe a global threat even when she’s still farming.
Here Ashe converts a 2 v 2 fight at mid into a 3 v 2 without leaving her lane.
When the arrow hits Katarina, her allies grab an easy kill, forcing Diana to fall back to the protection of her turret.
Whenever you’re recalling, check the status of your teammates.
While you’re in base, Enchanted Crystal Arrow has a clear shot down all three lanes.
As Shen retreats from Vladimir, Ashe lands a nice long-range arrow, stunning him alone under the turret.
The long stun duration allows the turret to kill him from almost full health as Vladimir tries to run away.
As her teammates gather to attempt Dragon, Ashe uses this opportunity to Hawkshot and scout for enemies.
Spotting the incoming enemy team, the reveal gives her teammates enough warning to reposition
and initiate onto Thresh as Ashe follows up with Enchanted Crystal Arrow.
The area of effect slow from her ultimate keeps the opposing team grouped up while she lines up her first Volley.
Ashe cleans up this fight using the slow from Frost Shot to prevent any escape
and casting Volley each time an opponent attempts to break line of sight around terrain.
Ashe runs into Vayne while attempting to help Fizz steal the enemy blue buff.
Using Frost Shot to slow Vayne's pursuit, Ashe expects Vayne to dive after Fizz for the kill.
Instead, Vayne flashes over the opposite wall, almost making a clean getaway.
Using Hawkshot and the vision from allied minions,
Ashe aims Enchanted Crystal Arrow to stun Vayne and get in range for a final Volley.
Late game, Ashe becomes a nearly uncatchable kiting machine.
With enough attack speed, she can hold any enemy at bay nearly indefinitely.
Here, Trundle makes a futile attempt to chase down Ashe and Orianna, but can’t make any headway thanks to their combined slows.
When building Ashe, try an offensive mix of damage, attack speed, and mobility to complement her freezing spells.
Remember that the guaranteed critical strike from Ashe’s passive
makes Infinity Edge a particularly enticing buy thanks to the increased crit damage.
For Runes, try Attack Damage Marks, Armor Seals, Magic Resist Glyphs, and Lifesteal Quintessences.
For Masteries, try 21/0/9 taking attack speed, damage and critical strike bonuses in Offense,
along with mana regeneration and summoner spell cooldowns in Utility.
For Summoner Spells, try Barrier or Cleanse, and Flash,
which will allow you to survive in team fights by running away or removing crowd control.
Thanks for tuning into the Ashe Champion Spotlight.
Please subscribe to the Riot Games YouTube channel and leave us your comments just below the video!

comments.text:
Ashe is completely outclassed in every way in comparison to nearly all 
other ADC champs. Don't even try.

Caitlyn's passive will give you more damage in half the charge-time, her Q 
will clear minion waves more effectively, her W is an infinitely more 
effective escape than Ashe's Frost Shot/Volley combo, her E can grant site 
over a larger area and at a drastically lower CD, and her ult, while not 
global, still has a gigantic range and is a more effective damage-dealer. 
And Cait's not even the best ADC champ there is.

You want to know how to play Ashe right? Swap to Caitlyn, for starters.﻿

comments.author: Skillshots

comments.text:
as a Diamond division player. Ashe is my favorite champion who help me 
climb the rank. When i was in bronze i played Vayne, Caitlyn,... Now Ashe 
is the beast.That big ass arrow is like a Leona's Solarflare, that W is a 
good kiting tools (2,4sec 7 arrows 35% slow please) the E passive help 
balance the gold if lose lane or keeping me ahead (1000+ more gold with 
avarice blade) . And E active help give vision which win teamfight most of 
the time (baron, dragon, jungle invade, bait, teleport,...). You can't 
ward, use Caitlyn wWwhen enemy are grouped, bushes will be a big 
disadvantage. (Flash combo = end game), while Ashe ult = 3.5s stun, 3s aoe 
slow.
comments.author: Trí Dương

comments.text:
I have to disagree.. I dont play Ashe much, and Im not claiming to be an 
amazing player, but I have barely less than a 100% win ratio with Ashe. 0 
escape abilities, but if you position well, Ashe is a beast. She can peel 
pretty well for herself and kiting becomes extremely easy on her with her 
slows and stun. Shes also has a really good initiation which not many 
Marksmen can provide. Im not saying Ashe is extremely god tier, but you're 
giving her way too little credit.
comments.author: Cesar Segura

comments.text:
Well, hey, if you want to try her because you find her fun, be my guest. My 
advice was for people who wanted to play to win, so it obviously doesn't 
apply. Just don't say you didn't get fair warning if you find yourself 
losing a lot against a bunch of powergamers or tryhards or what-have-you 
that are actually rather common in LoL... and that's going to be a feat, 
since if you lose, your team loses with you, and the League's community 
doesn't have a particularly strong reputation for being sympathetic. Or 
quiet.

But again, if that's a non-issue, go nuts with Ashe. Build her Tank or AP, 
for all I care.

But for the record? I've played overpowered champs and won and underpowered 
champs and lost, and I greatly preferred the former over the latter.

Nice username, btw.
+That One Guy from the Old Spice Commercial Who's Always Moving From Scene 
to Scene
comments.author: PeterDivine

comments.author: Erinthebunny

comments.text:
Ashe is a bad champion in general. Her passive is rubbish, her Q is ok, her 
W is excellent, her E is ok although the CD could be lowered (I do not moan 
about the CD though) and her ultimate is a hit or miss and could be better. 
Her defence is quite bad as well. Supposedly, if you end up with more kills 
than deaths (13/2 e.g.) , then it's probably due to you playing against bad 
champions or players. 

P.S. I use Ashe as my main champion so I know what I am on about.﻿
